column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Passwords are required for many computer programs and websites. A password should be tough to crack (that is, someone should not be able to figure it out easily), but should be easy to remember.

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: 1. You want to build a security code based on 2 outcomes, H and T, from flipping a coin repeatedly. To break the code, a hacker has to guess the exact pattern of heads and tails in your coin toss.

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: a. In how many ways can 2 coins land? List the possibilities and also write the answer as a power of 2.

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: b. In how many ways can 3 coins land? List the possibilities and also write the answer as a power of 2.

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: c. In how many ways can  8, 24, and 48 coins land? Write the answers as powers of 2.

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: d. Would you ever use this type of code? Why or why not?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: 2. You want to create a pass code  with digits from 0 to 9, and  repeating digits are allowed. To gain access with the pass code, a hacker has to have all digits of the code correct.

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: a. How many pass codes are  available if 3 digits are used?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: b. How many more pass codes are available if 4 digits are allowed?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: c. If a hacker can try 50 possible pass codes in 1 minute, what is the minimum amount of time it would take to check all the possible pass codes with 4 digits?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: d. How would increasing the pass code to 5 digits change the time it would take to check all the combinations?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: 3. You want to pick a password using any of the 26 letters in the alphabet, all lowercase, and repeating letters are allowed.

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: a. How many passwords can you choose that have 4 letters?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: b. If a hacker can try 25 possible passwords in 1 minute, how long would it take to check all the passwords that are 4 letters long?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: c. You can use any of the 26 letters and any of the digits from 0 to 9 to create a password with 4 characters. By what percentage does the possible number of passwords increase?

column2: Creating Passwords - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: 4. What are some recommendations you would make to someone who wants to create a password or security code that is difficult to break? What are some potential difficulties with implementing your recommendations?
